articles.title: Living Data Tutorials
articles.description: Open educational resources from the Living Data Project.
articles.contents:
We are a group of early career researchers from Canada who created a series of curated datasets with accompanying R-based tutorials. The six tutorials are based on Canadian open datasets with accompanying R code that can be used in undergraduate courses in ecology and evolutionary biology.
We designed the tutorials to teach, illustrate, and support exploration of core concepts in ecology and evolutionary biology. The tutorials span a variety of topics, skill levels, and formats to allow instructors to use as is or modify according to their needs. Please consult our guidelines for instructors for recommendations on how to use our tutorials in the classroom.

articles.title: Guidelines for instructors
articles.description: Here we provide guidelines to help instructors implement our tutorials in their courses.
articles.contents:
General usage
Implementation in the classroom
Our tutorials were designed to be pre-packaged, portable, and ready to use. Thus, the easiest way to implement them in the classroom is to share the link to our website with students so that they can dive-in directly in the tutorials section.
Integration into a lesson
Each tutorial requires between one and three hours to be fully completed depending on the tutorial and studentâ€™s skill level. We recommend that instructors plan on choosing one tutorial per lesson as concepts do not overlap across tutorials. This would include a short introduction to the tutorial and dataset so that students are acquainted with the ecological theory, concepts, and ideas behind the data.
60 minute lesson plan example
To do: Build the skeleton
10 min overview of topics covered and/or referenced in the tutorial
To make this a longer discussion for a larger course, you could include examples of recent papers drawing important conclusions about the topic at hand based on skills taught in the tutorials
Reuse
Our objective was to provide instructors with tutorials spanning a wide-range of skill levels so that they can implement them at different undergraduate levels (1st, 2nd, and 3rd year students).
Instructors can also reuse our tutorials under our license terms to adapt the content to their specific needs. This requires to download the files of a specific tutorial hosted on GitHub to modify it locally.
Here are the links to the GitHub repositories:
Disease Modelling in Mule Deer
Community Ecology: Hemlock Looper Outbreak on Anticosti Island
Tree Diversity & Dendrochronology in Alberta, BC Forests
R Basics & Data Exploration Using Tree Swallow Life History Data
Sexual Dimorphism & Sexual Selection in Tree Swallows
Understanding Biodiversity with Metrics & Rank Abundance Curves
If you have any suggestions on improvements, you can also clone our repositories locally, implement your changes, and create a pull request.
